title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with specific duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will consider the amount of money spent on campaigns, the qualifications of candidates, the trust in the political process, and media access for the electorate. The Federal office aims to promote trust and confidence in the political process among the electorate by ensuring access to media for informed candidate positions on issues. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected by majority vote within 7 days of all appointments. Within 7 days of all appointments, the Commission members must select a chairperson by majority vote. If the chairperson position remains vacant after 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive daily pay equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission members must select a chairperson within 7 days of all appointments. If the position remains vacant after 30 days, all members will be discharged. Each member is entitled to receive daily pay equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule. Six members constitute a quorum, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. Meetings are called by the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. The chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff without following standard appointment procedures. They can also procure temporary services as needed. Additionally, there are fast track procedures for recommendations. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. Recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns may be included, with bills prepared for implementation if 7 or more members agree on a recommendation. The implementing bills will be submitted with the report for Congress to consider. Recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns may be included, with bills prepared for implementation if 7 or more members agree on a recommendation. The implementing bills will be given expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for this Act.
